replies.bodyText:
mTextView is assigned when doInBackground is called from a parameter, and used in onPostExecute without any checks. If there were cases, when it wasn't provided correctly, I think this class would crash all the time, so I think it should be save to use it here.
As to why this is better than AnkiDroidApp's resources: mTextView's resources are created/updated with the correct language, when the DeckViewer gets refreshed. So this way we save:

The import of AnkiDroidApp into the file.
The need to update AnkiDroidApp's resources with the correct language during runtime.

timeline.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText:
Can do that, but I'm unsure, which exceptions we should catch? All? This is (as far as I looked up) considered bad practice. And as long as we don't know, which exceptions might occur, we can't narrow it down.
Do you have a specific reason why you want a try-catch block here? Do you want it as a temporary measure, so when things get rolled out and it fails for 1% or the users, the impact gets reduced and the block gets removed later on, when no crashes occur?
If you want a exception handler here, I can add it.
replies.author: Arthus

replies.bodyText:
TL;DR: Yes, but discussion is valuable, this is my opinion, and disagreements are more than welcome

Java has a distinction between Exception and Error. Typically, you shouldn't try to catch an Error (OutOfMemoryError for example).
You shouldn't catch and ignore exceptions that you can't resolve, so somewhere higher up the stack will handle them
You should handle exceptions individually, as you have the most context as to what's gone wrong and can take specific corrective action
In this case, we can't easily anticipate all of the exceptions that will be thrown, and the list of exceptions that may be thrown is large.
It's unlikely that any of the exceptions that we catch have a specific corrective action to be taken
Throwing would crash the app, which is a serious issue if it occurs on startup. Even more serious as the base context may be attached before our error handler is initialised


In our case:

We're at the point in the stack where we have a reasonable default to return on any exception
The catch block is very unlikely to be executed
If the catch block is executed, we call AnkiDroidApp.sendExceptionReport(e, "updateContextWithLanguage");

This allows us to diagnose the crash, the user will be notified of the problem, or the app will work as normal for them
This will do nothing before ACRA is set up, but we'll get an exception report on the second call


It's a lot of effort to enumerate the possible exceptions which can be thrown

Even if we did, it's unlikely that any of them have a reasonable corrective action to take over the generic: "Return the context that we were provided with".


It's reasonable for the contract of the method to state that the input will be returned if there is a failure.


Counterpoints:

A catch Exception will catch DeadSystemException, but we're dead in the water anyway if this occurs.
replies.author: david-allison-1

replies.bodyText:
Catching Exception is not a bad practice, you are reading information from people that have studied a lot I think, but not programmed in the real world.
If you don't catch Exception the app will crash here, which is terrible. It's as simple as that.
Further, as David mentioned, no one else can handle any errors coming out of here better than we can, so you catch everything and return a reasonable default.
Programming is pragmatic not dogmatic. Catching Exception is fine. Catching Error sometimes is fine. Exponential cost algorithms are sometimes fine. Not failing fast is sometimes fine. It all depends on the cost/benefit in the area you are programming in.

timeline.author: mikehardy

replies.bodyText:
Yeah, there are a lot "interesting" things in Android's locale handling, e.g. the differences in toString() and toLanguageTag().
The change here takes into account that the returned string from Locale.getDefault().toString() can also be more than 2 characters long. toString() returns some Android style language code using underscores _. The constructor of Locale expects ISO 639 style language codes (those actually have 3 characters by default) or "a Language subtag" (whatever this means, could support the result of toString, could not. Not properly documented in the SDK).
